metadata.title: Industrial Home Work of the Dennison Manufacturing Company of Framingham, Massachusetts, 1912-1935

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the decline of home work due to technological advancements and social pressures, highlighting labor displacement.

design.sample_characteristics: Former Dennison tag stringers and other employees, primarily from Framingham, Massachusetts.

dependent_variables.displaced: Home workers displaced by stringing machines.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Not explicitly detailed, but implied reduction in home work opportunities.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Piece rates were low, and home work was among the lowest paid types of work.

text_fragments: 'Money was hard to come by in the early 1930s and we all had to pitch in to make ends meet.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study provides detailed accounts of the home work system, the role of children, and the community's reliance on this work.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The Great Depression significantly impacted employment and production at Dennison Manufacturing.
historical_context.institutional_context: Massachusetts child labor laws and the National Industrial Recovery Act influenced the decline of home work.

outcomes.main_findings: Home work at Dennison Manufacturing declined due to technological advancements and social pressures, but was not fully replaced by machines until the 1930s.
outcomes.conclusions: The decline of home work was driven by technological limitations, economic conditions, and social pressures against child labor.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that home work provided essential income for families during economic hardships, but also involved child labor.
